Sure, here are a few examples of small riffs or motifs that can be transposed and used in different musical contexts using only the notes provided (F3, Bb3, C4, Eb4, F4, G4, Ab4, Bb4, C5):

1. A simple riff that uses the notes of the F Major chord (F, A, C) : F3, F4, A4, C5, F3, A4, C5, F4
2. A motif that uses the notes of the Ab Major chord (Ab, C, Eb) : Ab4, C5, Eb5, Ab4, C5, Eb5, Ab4, C5
3. A riff that uses the notes of the Bb Major chord (Bb, D, F) : Bb3, D4, F4, Bb4, D5, F5, Bb4, D5
4. A motif that uses the notes of the F minor chord (F, Ab, C) : F3, Ab4, C5, F4, Ab4, C5, F4, Ab4
5. A riff that uses the notes of the Eb Major chord (Eb, G, Bb) : Eb4, G4, Bb4, Eb5, G5, Bb5, Eb5, G5
6. A motif that uses the notes of the C Major chord (C, E, G) : C4, E4, G4, C5, E5, G5, C5, E5

These are just a few examples of small riffs or motifs that can be transposed and used in different musical contexts using the notes provided (F3, Bb3, C4, Eb4, F4, G4, Ab4, Bb4, C5). Remember that you can experiment with different melodies, chord progressions and rhythms to create your own unique sound.
